_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Other Farm Product Raw Material Merchant Wholesalers

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This is an executive summary of the policies, procedures and activities for compliance with the EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Requirements - Risk Management Program pursuant to Title 40 Part 68 of the Code of Federal Regulations (40 CFR 68) for Helm Fertilizer's (Helm's) Memphis, Tennessee facility (Memphis facility).



The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source [40 CFR 68.155(a)]:

The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies are addressed in the individual RMP and PSM procedures, which detail the program requirements as well as how Helm complies with the applicable requirements.  The Memphis facility is a non-responding facility for releases of the RMP-listed chemicals, so the site utilizes an Emergency Action Plan.  



The stationary source and regulated substances handled [40 CFR 68.155(b)]:

The primary activity at the facility is the storage and blending of fertilizers for sale to farmers and co-ops.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for both direct application and for blending into mixed-grade fertilizers for crop production nutrients.



The Helm Memphis facility stores and handles anhydrous ammonia and aqueous ammonia, which are subject to reporting under this filing to the EPA.  The facility receives anhydrous ammonia via barges and railcars, and the anhydrous ammonia is stored onsite in numerous storage vessels until it can be loaded into trucks for shipment.  In addition, the facility utilizes an aqua ammonia converter to add water to the anhydrous ammonia to create 19.5% and 29.4% aqueous ammonia, which is stored at the facility until it is loaded for shipment at a common loadout location. 

 

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps [40 CFR 68.155(c)]:

The Helm Memphis facility has implemented the Program Level 3 prevention program requirements under the RMP regulations.  The required elements of the RMP p

revention program are listed below:



     Employee Participation

     Process Safety Information

     Process Hazard Analysis

     Operating Procedures

     Training

     Contractors

     Pre-startup Safety Review

     Mechanical Integrity

     Hot Work Permit

     Management of Change

     Incident Investigation

     Compliance Audits



In addition, the facility meets the requirements of the RMP Emergency Planning and Response element as detailed below. These items, their specific requirements, and how the Helm Memphis facility complies with the requirements are addressed in the procedural documents.



The five-year accident history [40 CFR 68.155(d)]:

The Helm Memphis facility has had zero RMP reportable incidents in the previous five years.



The emergency response program [40 CFR 68.155(e)]:

In the event of an emergency, the Memphis facility will notify the local emergency responders and will evacuate their employees when needed.  Additional details related to emergency procedures can be located in the facility's Emergency Action Plan.



Planned changes to improve safety [40 CFR 68.155(f)]:

The facility completed a process hazard analysis (PHA) in July 2018 that identified several recommendations for enhanced process safety.  These recommendations are summarized in the PHA report and are currently under evaluation.
